zendir.utils package

Submodules

zendir.utils.exception module

exception zendir.utils.exception.ZendirException(message: str)

Bases: Exception

The Zendir Exception class defines a custom exception that is able to track errors with the Zendir API. Any connection errors or issues with the objects will throw an Zendir API if there are configuration issues.

zendir.utils.helper module

This modules assists with some helper functions for defining what values can be turned into JSON and whether GUID IDs are valid. This also includes some methods for serializing and deserializing JSON data to standard formats.

zendir.utils.helper.deserialize(value: any) → any

Deserializes the value from a JSON serializable format. This will convert the value into a numpy array if it is a list of numbers or a datetime string into a datetime object.

Parameters:

value (any) – The value to deserialize

Returns:

The deserialized value

Return type:

any

zendir.utils.helper.empty_guid() → str

Returns an empty GUID, which is a string of zeros.

Returns:

An empty GUID

Return type:

str

zendir.utils.helper.is_valid_guid(guid: str) → bool

Determines if a parsed GUID, as a string, is valid. This will ensure that it is of the correct format.

Parameters:

guid (str) – The unique GUID of the object, in the correct form

Returns:

A flag whether the GUID is valid

Return type:

bool

zendir.utils.helper.serialize(value: any) → any

Serializes the value into a JSON serializable format. This will convert the value into a list if it is a numpy array or a datetime into a string.

Parameters:

value (any) – The value to serialize

Returns:

The serialized value

Return type:

any

zendir.utils.helper.validate_type(type: str) → str

Validates the type of the object and ensures that it is in the correct format.

Parameters:

type (str) – The type of the object to validate

Returns:

The validated type with the namespace

Return type:

str

zendir.utils.printer module

This module contains helper functions for printing lines to the console. By default, any calls made to these functions will not print any data. If the verbosity is enabled, then data will be printed to the console.

zendir.utils.printer.ERROR_VERBOSITY: int = 4

Defines the verbosity for only errors coming from the API and requests.

zendir.utils.printer.INFO_VERBOSITY: int = 2

Defines the verbosity for all information coming from the API and requests.

zendir.utils.printer.LOG_VERBOSITY: int = 0

Defines the verbosity for all messages coming from the API and requests.

zendir.utils.printer.SUCCESS_VERBOSITY: int = 1

Defines the verbosity for all success and errors coming from the API and requests.

zendir.utils.printer.WARNING_VERBOSITY: int = 3

Defines the verbosity for any warnings or errors coming from the API and requests.

zendir.utils.printer.add_callback(callback: callable) → None

Adds a callback function that will be called whenever a message is printed. This can be used to log messages or perform other actions when printing.

Parameters:

callback (callable) – The callback function to add

zendir.utils.printer.clear() → None

Clears the console output, if possible. This is useful for clearing the screen before printing new data.

zendir.utils.printer.debug(data: str) → None

Prints debug messages for testing certain features to the console. This will always print provided the printer is enabled, regardless of the verbosity level.

Parameters:

data (str) – The raw data to print to the screen

zendir.utils.printer.display_time(enable: bool) → None

Defines whether time should be enabled on the printing output messages or not.

Parameters:

  • enable – A flag for enabling the timestamp on the print lines

  • type – bool

zendir.utils.printer.error(data: str) → None

Prints error messages to the console, providing information about errors that occurred. This requires any valid verbosity level.

Parameters:

data (str) – The raw data to print to the screen

zendir.utils.printer.info(data: str) → None

Prints information messages to the console, providing information about potential results. This requires at least a INFO_VERBOSITY level.

Parameters:

data (str) – The raw data to print to the screen

zendir.utils.printer.log(data: str) → None

Prints general log text to the console, providing some information about the API calls or requests. This requires a LOG_VERBOSITY level.

Parameters:

data (str) – The raw data to print to the screen

zendir.utils.printer.output(data: str, color: str = '') → None

Outputs text to the console assuming that the verbose level is enabled for that type.

Parameters:

  • data (str) – The raw data to print to the screen

  • color (str) – The unique character code format for the color or type of text

zendir.utils.printer.remove_callback(callback: callable) → None

Removes a callback function from the list of callbacks.

Parameters:

callback (callable) – The callback function to remove

zendir.utils.printer.set_verbosity(level: int) → None

Updates the verbosity level of the printing to a particular verbosity level. The levels are either LOG_VERBOSITY, WARNING_VERBOSITY, SUCCESS_VERBOSITY or ERROR_VERBOSITY.

Parameters:

level (str) – The verbosity level to initialise the printer to

zendir.utils.printer.success(data: str) → None

Prints success messages coming from the simulation or the API calls to the screen. This requires at least a SUCCESS_VERBOSITY level.

Parameters:

data (str) – The raw data to print to the screen

zendir.utils.printer.warning(data: str) → None

Prints warning messages to the console, providing information about potential errors. This requires at least a WARNING_VERBOSITY level.

Parameters:

data (str) – The raw data to print to the screen

zendir.utils.runner module

This modules assists with some helper functions for running a certain number of simulations in parallel, using the asyncio library. This is useful for quickly running simulations.

zendir.utils.runner.run_simulation(client: Client, main: callable, *args, dispose: bool = True, **kwargs) → None

Run a simulation with the provided client and main function. This is a synchronous function that creates a simulation handle and runs the main function with the simulation. The main function must have the first parameter as the simulation handle, and can take any number of additional parameters and keyword arguments.

Parameters:

  • client (Client) – The client to use for the simulation.

  • main (callable) – The main function to run with the simulation.

  • args (tuple) – Additional positional arguments to pass to the main function.

  • dispose (bool) – Whether to dispose of the simulation handle after running

  • kwargs (dict) – Additional keyword arguments to pass to the main function.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

zendir.utils.runner.run_simulations(client: Client, number: int, main: callable, *args, dispose: bool = True, **kwargs) → None

Run a number of simulations in parallel with the provided client and main function. This is a synchronous function that creates a simulation handle for each simulation and runs the main function with the simulation. The main function must have the first parameter as the simulation handle, the second parameter being the index and can take any number of additional parameters and keyword arguments.

Parameters:

  • client (Client) – The client to use for the simulations.

  • number (int) – The number of simulations to run.

  • main (callable) – The main function to run with each simulation.

  • args (tuple) – Additional positional arguments to pass to the main function.

  • dispose (bool) – Whether to dispose of the simulation handles after running

  • kwargs (dict) – Additional keyword arguments to pass to the main function.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None
